Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Characterization and Modeling of Natural Fiber Polymer Matrix Composites for Correlating Natural Fiber/Matrix Morphology with Viscoelastic Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this collaborative award is to elucidate the properties of natural fibers grown in a controlled environment and retted to form structural fibers through environmentally benign methods. The research is focused on examing the effect of cross sectional architectures in fibers and their impact on fiber properties. Modeling of the fiber properties and their introduction into compostable thermoplastic biopolymers will be conducted. We will conduct mechanical testing and micromechanics modeling to enable a comprehensive basis for design of natural fiber composites.

If successful, the baseline developed through this investigation will form a blueprint for a new class of fibers. The natural high resilience that plants show will be brought to bear new composites. The impact of the effort is both immediate in the increased understanding of what improves the properties of natural fiber based compostable structures but in long term development of fiber composites. The project will bring collaborative partnerships between University of Texas at Dallas and University of North Texas in Denton and enhanced interdisciplinary experiences for students in plant biology, materials characterization, and mechanics. Outreach partnerships between the two institutions and Society of Women Engineer chapters will be conducted.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biofibers such as kenaf fibers are fast growing, and can be matured in short period of time, on the order of 6 months. The yield is high, for example, for kenaf plants, the yield can reach several tons per acre. Applications of kenaf fibers include newsprint, textile, oil sorbent for structural applications for automotive, cellular phones, boats, and buildings. Kenaf fibers have low density, and give high stiffness and strength per unit mass. They also provide excellent acoustic absorbing and thermal insulation capabilities. They are viable substitutes for synthetic fibers such as carbon fibers for use in polymer fiber composites. In this project, the kenaf fibers are used as reinforcing fibers in polymers to provide stiffness and strength in composites. Kenaf fibers with different growth stages were embedded in a polymer matrix. The cellular structures of the kenaf fibers were observed for different growth stage, various retting techniques were used to identify appropriate techniques that provide desired properties. Chopped kenaf fibers were embedded in a polymer to form a composite. The composites were tested under loading conditions from low speed to high speed to evaluate the viscoelastic properties. At high speed a high impact facility was used in coonection with ultra-high speed photography to observe the deformation and failure behavior of the material. It was determined that the kenaf fibers were able to induce crystallization over a large volume in the polymer, and therefore enhance the mechanical properties.  

In addition to Kenaf fibers, in this project, funds were also contributed to the support for inventing a highly stretchable artificial muscle. Well aligned carbon nanotube sheet was used to wrap around a highly-stretched rubber core to form a conductive fiber. The fiber maintains its electrical conductivity over large stretch ratio, up to 14 times of its initial length. On the coated carbon nanotube sheath, another layer of rubber was applied. Subsequently a carbon nanotube sheet was applied on top the rubber to form two concentric, electrically conductive carbon nanotube sheaths. The result is a capacitor that can sense deformation, and also provide actuation when a varying voltage is applied. Demonstration of very large linear range for strain sensing and robust repeatable torsional actuations was made. This core/sheath structures have potential for use in medical device, as artificial muscles, in textiles, and other areas. This work was published in Science in 2015, and the work cited as "Stretchable Electronics Get Stretchier" was selected as one of the 100 Top Stories in 2015 in Discover magazine. 

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2015
Modified by: Hongbing Lu
